docs.title: Crier
docs.text:
Cross-post your content everywhere.

Crier is a CLI tool that publishes your markdown content to multiple platforms with a single command. Like a town crier announcing your content to the world.

docs.title: Why Crier?
docs.text:
Content creators face a fragmented distribution landscape. You write a blog post, then must manually:

  • Publish to your blog
  • Cross-post to dev.to, Hashnode, Medium for discovery
  • Announce on Bluesky, Mastodon, Twitter for reach
  • Send to newsletter subscribers
  • Post to Discord/Telegram communities

Crier automates this. Write once, publish everywhere.

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text:
• Write Once, Publish Everywhere — Your markdown file is the source of truth
  • Unix Philosophy — Small tool, one job, composes well with other tools
  • Developer-First — Markdown + YAML front matter, CLI-only, no GUI
  • Platform Agnostic — Easy to add new platforms

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
# Configure platforms
crier config set devto.api_key YOUR_KEY
crier config set bluesky.api_key "handle.bsky.social:app-password"

# Create a profile for blog platforms
crier config profile set blogs devto hashnode ghost

# Publish to all blog platforms
crier publish my-post.md --profile blogs

# See what's missing
crier audit ./posts --profile blogs

# Backfill missing publications
crier backfill ./posts --profile blogs

docs.text: Category Platforms Blog dev.to, Hashnode, Medium, Ghost, WordPress Newsletter Buttondown Social Bluesky, Mastodon, LinkedIn, Threads, Twitter Announcement Telegram, Discord

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide walks you through installing Crier and publishing your first post.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: pip install crier

docs.title: Configure Your First Platform
docs.text:
Let's start with dev.to, which has a simple API key setup:

  1. Go to dev.to/settings/extensions
  2. Generate an API key
  3. Configure Crier:
crier config set devto.api_key YOUR_API_KEY

Verify it works:

crier doctor

You should see dev.to listed as "Healthy".

docs.title: Create a Markdown Post
docs.text:
Create a file called my-first-post.md:

---
title: "My First Cross-Posted Article"
description: "Testing out Crier for cross-posting"
tags: [testing, crier, automation]
canonical_url: https://myblog.com/my-first-post
published: true
---

This is my first post published with Crier!

## Why Crier?

Because manually posting to multiple platforms is tedious.

docs.title: Preview Before Publishing
docs.text:
Use --dry-run to see what would be published:

crier publish my-first-post.md --dry-run

docs.title: Publish
docs.text:
When you're ready:

crier publish my-first-post.md --to devto

docs.title: Check Publication Status
docs.text: crier status my-first-post.md

docs.title: Add More Platforms
docs.text:
Configure additional platforms:

# Bluesky
crier config set bluesky.api_key "handle.bsky.social:app-password"

# Mastodon
crier config set mastodon.api_key "mastodon.social:access-token"

# Hashnode
crier config set hashnode.api_key "your-token"

See Platforms for setup instructions for each platform.

docs.title: Create Publishing Profiles
docs.text:
Group platforms for convenience:

# Create profiles
crier config profile set blogs devto hashnode
crier config profile set social bluesky mastodon

# Publish to a profile
crier publish my-post.md --profile blogs

docs.title: Backfill & Audit
docs.text: Backfill lets you publish old content to platforms you've added later. Audit shows you what's missing.

docs.title: The Problem
docs.text:
You have existing blog posts that weren't published to all platforms:

  • You wrote posts before using Crier
  • You added a new platform (e.g., Bluesky)
  • Some publications failed and you didn't retry

docs.title: Audit: See What's Missing
docs.text: The audit command scans your content and shows what's missing where.

docs.title: Audit a Directory
docs.text:
crier audit ./posts

docs.title: Audit Against Specific Platforms
docs.text:
# Check only certain platforms
crier audit ./posts --to devto --to bluesky

# Check against a profile
crier audit ./posts --profile social

docs.title: Backfill: Publish Missing Content
docs.text: The backfill command publishes content that's missing from platforms.

docs.title: Preview First
docs.text:
Always preview before publishing:

crier backfill ./posts --dry-run

docs.title: Backfill Everything
docs.text:
crier backfill ./posts

You'll be prompted to confirm before publishing.

docs.title: Backfill to Specific Platforms
docs.text:
# Only backfill to Bluesky
crier backfill ./posts --to bluesky

# Only backfill to a profile
crier backfill ./posts --profile social

docs.title: Skip Confirmation
docs.text: crier backfill ./posts --yes

docs.title: Backfill a Single File
docs.text: crier backfill my-old-post.md

docs.title: Typical Workflow
docs.text:
1. Audit to see the current state: 

    crier audit ./posts --profile everything

  2. Dry run to preview what would happen: 

    crier backfill ./posts --profile everything --dry-run

  3. Backfill to publish missing content: 

    crier backfill ./posts --profile everything

  4. Verify with another audit: 

    crier audit ./posts --profile everything

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Backfill only publishes to platforms where content is not already published
  • Publications are recorded in the registry after success
  • Failed publications can be retried by running backfill again
  • Use --dry-run liberally to preview changes

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Crier stores configuration in ~/.config/crier/config.yaml.

docs.title: Via CLI
docs.text:
crier config set devto.api_key YOUR_KEY
crier config set bluesky.api_key "handle.bsky.social:app-password"

docs.title: Via Environment Variables
docs.text:
Environment variables take precedence over the config file:

export CRIER_DEVTO_API_KEY=your_key
export CRIER_BLUESKY_API_KEY="handle.bsky.social:app-password"

docs.title: Via Config File
docs.text:
Edit ~/.config/crier/config.yaml directly:

platforms:
  devto:
    api_key: your_key_here
  bluesky:
    api_key: "handle.bsky.social:app-password"
  mastodon:
    api_key: "mastodon.social:access-token"

docs.title: Publishing Profiles
docs.text: Profiles let you group platforms for convenience.

docs.title: Creating Profiles
docs.text:
# Create basic profiles
crier config profile set blogs devto hashnode ghost
crier config profile set social bluesky mastodon

# Profiles can reference other profiles (composition)
crier config profile set everything blogs social

docs.title: Using Profiles
docs.text:
# Publish to all platforms in a profile
crier publish post.md --profile blogs

# Combine profile with additional platforms
crier publish post.md --profile blogs --to telegram

# Audit against a profile
crier audit ./posts --profile social

# Backfill using a profile
crier backfill ./posts --profile everything

docs.title: Managing Profiles
docs.text:
# Show all profiles
crier config profile show

# Show a specific profile
crier config profile show blogs

# Delete a profile
crier config profile delete old-profile

docs.title: Config File Format
docs.text:
platforms:
  devto:
    api_key: xxx
  bluesky:
    api_key: handle.bsky.social:xxx

profiles:
  blogs:
    - devto
    - hashnode
    - ghost
  social:
    - bluesky
    - mastodon
  everything:
    - blogs
    - social

docs.title: Viewing Configuration
docs.text:
# Show configured platforms and profiles (keys are masked)
crier config show

# Validate API keys work
crier doctor

# List all available platforms
crier platforms

docs.title: Configuration Path
docs.text:
Override the config file location:

export CRIER_CONFIG=/path/to/config.yaml

docs.title: GitHub Action Integration
docs.text: Auto-publish content when you push to your repository.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. You push a new/updated markdown file to posts/
  2. GitHub Action triggers
  3. Crier checks what's missing from your configured platforms
  4. Crier publishes missing content
  5. The publication registry is committed back to your repo

docs.title: Quick Setup (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to set up GitHub Actions is with the init-action command:

# In your content repository:
cd ~/repos/my-blog

# Set up workflow and secrets automatically
crier init-action

This command will: 1. Create .github/workflows/crier-publish.yml in your repo 2. Set all your configured API keys as GitHub repository secrets

Options:

# Preview what would be done
crier init-action --dry-run

# Specify a custom content path
crier init-action --content-path blog/articles

# Skip confirmation prompts
crier init-action --yes

Requirements: - GitHub CLI (gh) must be installed and authenticated - Run gh auth login if not already authenticated

docs.title: Manual Setup
docs.text: If you prefer to set things up manually:

docs.title: 1. Add Secrets to Your Repository
docs.text:
Go to your repository's Settings → Secrets and variables → Actions and add:

Secret Name Value CRIER_DEVTO_API_KEY Your dev.to API key CRIER_BLUESKY_API_KEY handle.bsky.social:app-password CRIER_MASTODON_API_KEY instance.social:access-token CRIER_HASHNODE_API_KEY Your Hashnode token

Only add secrets for platforms you want to use.

docs.title: 2. Create the Workflow File
docs.text:
Create .github/workflows/crier-publish.yml in your repository:

name: Auto-Publish Content

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
    paths:
      - 'posts/**/*.md'
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  publish:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0

      - uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.12'

      - name: Install Crier
        run: pip install crier

      - name: Publish new content
        env:
          CRIER_DEVTO_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CRIER_DEVTO_API_KEY }}
          CRIER_BLUESKY_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CRIER_BLUESKY_API_KEY }}
          CRIER_MASTODON_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CRIER_MASTODON_API_KEY }}
          CRIER_HASHNODE_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CRIER_HASHNODE_API_KEY }}
        run: |
          echo "=== Configured Platforms ==="
          crier platforms

          echo "=== Audit ==="
          crier audit ./posts || true

          echo "=== Publishing ==="
          crier backfill ./posts --yes || true

      - name: Commit registry
        run: |
          git config user.email "github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com"
          git config user.name "github-actions[bot]"

          if [ -d ".crier" ]; then
            git add .crier/
            git diff --staged --quiet || git commit -m "Update publication registry"
            git push
          fi

docs.title: 3. Customize for Your Repository
docs.text:
Change the posts path if your content is elsewhere:

paths:
  - 'content/**/*.md'  # or wherever your posts are

Add a profile for specific platforms:

First, create a crier config file in your repo at .crier/config.yaml:

profiles:
  blogs: [devto, hashnode]
  social: [bluesky, mastodon]
  all: [blogs, social]

Then update the workflow:

- name: Publish new content
  env:
    # ... secrets ...
  run: |
    crier backfill ./posts --profile blogs --yes

docs.title: Example: metafunctor Repository
docs.text:
For your metafunctor repo, create .github/workflows/crier-publish.yml:

name: Cross-Post Content

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
    paths:
      - 'posts/**/*.md'
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  crosspost:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0

      - uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.12'

      - run: pip install crier

      - name: Cross-post to platforms
        env:
          CRIER_DEVTO_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CRIER_DEVTO_API_KEY }}
          CRIER_BLUESKY_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CRIER_BLUESKY_API_KEY }}
        run: |
          crier audit ./posts
          crier backfill ./posts --yes

      - name: Save publication state
        run: |
          git config user.email "41898282+github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com"
          git config user.name "github-actions[bot]"
          git add .crier/ 2>/dev/null || true
          git diff --staged --quiet || git commit -m "📢 Update publication registry"
          git push

docs.title: How the Registry Works
docs.text:
The registry (.crier/registry.yaml) tracks what's been published:

posts:
  "posts/my-article.md":
    title: "My Article"
    publications:
      devto:
        id: "12345"
        url: https://dev.to/user/my-article
        published_at: 2025-01-15T10:00:00Z
      bluesky:
        id: "abc123"
        published_at: 2025-01-15T10:05:00Z

When the action runs: - crier backfill checks the registry - Only publishes to platforms where the post is not already recorded - Updates the registry after successful publications - Commits the registry back to your repo

This means: - A new post gets published to all platforms - An existing post is skipped (already in registry) - If you add a new platform, old posts get backfilled

docs.title: Manual Trigger
docs.text:
You can manually trigger the workflow from GitHub:

  1. Go to Actions tab in your repository
  2. Select the "Cross-Post Content" workflow
  3. Click Run workflow

This is useful for: - Initial backfill of existing content - Retrying failed publications - Testing your setup

docs.title: Publication Tracking
docs.text:
Crier tracks what content has been published where, enabling you to:

  • See publication status at a glance
  • Detect content changes since last publish
  • Identify what's missing from platforms
  • Backfill old content to new platforms

docs.title: The Registry
docs.text:
Publications are tracked in .crier/registry.yaml in your project directory.

version: 1
posts:
  "posts/my-article.md":
    title: "My Article"
    checksum: "a1b2c3d4"
    canonical_url: https://myblog.com/my-article
    publications:
      devto:
        id: "12345"
        url: https://dev.to/user/my-article
        published_at: 2025-01-15T10:00:00Z
      bluesky:
        id: "bsky123"
        url: https://bsky.app/profile/user/post/bsky123
        published_at: 2025-01-15T10:05:00Z

docs.title: Single File
docs.text:
crier status my-post.md

Shows: - Where the file is published - Publication dates - Whether content has changed since publishing

docs.title: All Tracked Posts
docs.text:
crier status --all

Lists all posts in the registry with their publication platforms.

docs.title: Automatic Tracking
docs.text:
When you publish with Crier, successful publications are automatically recorded:

crier publish my-post.md --to devto --to bluesky
# Registry is updated automatically

docs.title: Content Change Detection
docs.text:
Crier stores a checksum of each file. If you edit a file after publishing, crier status will show it has changed:

⚠ Content has changed since last publication

This helps you know which posts need updating on platforms.

docs.title: Registry Location
docs.text:
The registry is created in .crier/registry.yaml relative to your current directory. You can:

  • Commit it: Track publication history in version control
  • Gitignore it: Keep it local only
# .gitignore - if you don't want to track publication history
.crier/

docs.title: Platforms Overview
docs.text: Crier supports 13 platforms across four categories.

docs.title: Blog Platforms
docs.text:
Full markdown article publishing with metadata support.

Platform API Key Format Features dev.to api_key Full CRUD, tags, canonical URL Hashnode token or token:publication_id Full CRUD, tags Medium integration_token Publish only Ghost https://site:key_id:key_secret Full CRUD, self-hosted WordPress site:token or https://site:user:pass Full CRUD

docs.title: Newsletter Platforms
docs.text:
Publish to email subscribers.

Platform API Key Format Features Buttondown api_key Full CRUD

docs.title: Social Platforms
docs.text:
Short posts with link cards for announcing content.

Platform API Key Format Features Bluesky handle:app_password Posts with link cards Mastodon instance:access_token Toots with hashtags Threads user_id:access_token Posts (no edit) LinkedIn access_token Posts Twitter any (copy-paste mode) Generates tweet text

docs.title: Announcement Channels
docs.text:
Post to community channels/servers.

Platform API Key Format Features Telegram bot_token:chat_id Channel posts Discord webhook_url Webhook embeds

docs.title: Bluesky
docs.text: Bluesky is a decentralized social network. Crier creates short announcement posts with link cards.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings → App Passwords in Bluesky
  2. Create a new app password
  3. Configure Crier:
crier config set bluesky.api_key "yourhandle.bsky.social:xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx"

docs.title: API Key Format
docs.text:
handle:app_password
  • handle: Your full Bluesky handle (e.g., alice.bsky.social)
  • app_password: The app password you generated

docs.title: Features
docs.text: Feature Supported Publish ✓ Update ✗ List ✓ Delete ✓

docs.title: Post Format
docs.text:
Crier creates posts in this format:

Title of Your Post

Description (if provided)

#hashtag1 #hashtag2

https://your-canonical-url.com

Posts are limited to 300 characters. Crier automatically truncates if needed.

docs.title: CLI Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for all Crier commands.

docs.title: publish
docs.text:
Publish a markdown file to one or more platforms.

crier publish FILE [OPTIONS]

Arguments:

  • FILE — Path to the markdown file to publish

Options:

Option Description --to, -t PLATFORM Platform to publish to (can be repeated) --profile, -p NAME Use a predefined profile --draft Publish as draft --dry-run Preview without publishing

Examples:

# Publish to a single platform
crier publish post.md --to devto

# Publish to multiple platforms
crier publish post.md --to devto --to bluesky --to mastodon

# Use a profile
crier publish post.md --profile blogs

# Combine profile and additional platforms
crier publish post.md --profile blogs --to telegram

# Preview what would be published
crier publish post.md --profile everything --dry-run

# Publish as draft
crier publish post.md --to devto --draft

docs.title: status
docs.text:
Show publication status for a file or all tracked posts.

crier status [FILE] [OPTIONS]

Arguments:

  • FILE — (Optional) Path to a specific file

Options:

Option Description --all, -a Show all tracked posts

Examples:

# Status for a specific file
crier status my-post.md

# Status for all tracked posts
crier status --all

docs.title: audit
docs.text:
Audit content to see what's missing from platforms.

crier audit [PATH] [OPTIONS]

Arguments:

  • PATH — File or directory to audit (default: current directory)

Options:

Option Description --to, -t PLATFORM Only check specific platform(s) --profile, -p NAME Only check platforms in a profile

Examples:

# Audit all markdown files in current directory
crier audit

# Audit a specific directory
crier audit ./posts

# Audit against specific platforms
crier audit ./posts --to devto --to hashnode

# Audit against a profile
crier audit ./posts --profile blogs

docs.title: backfill
docs.text:
Publish content that's missing from platforms.

crier backfill PATH [OPTIONS]

Arguments:

  • PATH — File or directory to backfill

Options:

Option Description --to, -t PLATFORM Only publish to specific platform(s) --profile, -p NAME Only publish to platforms in a profile --dry-run Preview without publishing --yes, -y Skip confirmation prompt

Examples:

# Backfill a directory to all configured platforms
crier backfill ./posts

# Backfill to specific platforms
crier backfill ./posts --to bluesky

# Backfill using a profile
crier backfill ./posts --profile social

# Preview what would be published
crier backfill ./posts --dry-run

# Skip confirmation
crier backfill ./posts --yes

docs.title: update
docs.text:
Update an existing article on a platform.

crier update PLATFORM ARTICLE_ID --file FILE

Arguments:

  • PLATFORM — Platform name (e.g., devto, hashnode)
  • ARTICLE_ID — The article ID on the platform

Options:

Option Description --file, -f FILE Markdown file with updated content (required)

Examples:

crier update devto 12345 --file updated-post.md

docs.title: list
docs.text:
List your articles on a platform.

crier list PLATFORM [OPTIONS]

Arguments:

  • PLATFORM — Platform name

Options:

Option Description --limit, -n NUMBER Number of articles to show (default: 10)

Examples:

crier list devto
crier list devto --limit 20

docs.title: doctor
docs.text:
Check configuration and validate API keys.

crier doctor

Validates all configured API keys by making test requests to each platform.

docs.title: platforms
docs.text:
List all available platforms and their configuration status.

crier platforms

docs.title: init-action
docs.text:
Set up GitHub Action workflow and secrets for auto-publishing.

crier init-action [OPTIONS]

Creates the workflow file and configures GitHub repository secrets from your local crier config.

Options:

Option Description --content-path, -c PATH Custom path to content directory --dry-run Preview without making changes --yes, -y Skip confirmation prompts

Requirements:

  • GitHub CLI (gh) must be installed
  • Must be authenticated: gh auth login
  • Must be in a git repo with a GitHub remote

Examples:

# Standard setup (uses posts/ or content/)
crier init-action

# Preview what would be done
crier init-action --dry-run

# Custom content path
crier init-action --content-path blog/articles

# Non-interactive setup
crier init-action --yes

docs.title: config
docs.text: Manage Crier configuration.

docs.title: config set
docs.text:
Set a configuration value.

crier config set KEY VALUE

Examples:

crier config set devto.api_key YOUR_KEY
crier config set bluesky.api_key "handle.bsky.social:app-password"

docs.title: config show
docs.text:
Show current configuration (API keys are masked).

crier config show

docs.title: config profile set
docs.text:
Create or update a publishing profile.

crier config profile set NAME PLATFORMS...

Examples:

# Create a profile
crier config profile set blogs devto hashnode ghost

# Profiles can reference other profiles
crier config profile set everything blogs social

docs.title: config profile show
docs.text:
Show profiles.

crier config profile show [NAME]

docs.title: config profile delete
docs.text:
Delete a profile.

crier config profile delete NAME

docs.title: Front Matter Reference
docs.text: Crier reads YAML front matter from your markdown files.

docs.title: Basic Format
docs.text:
---
title: "Your Post Title"
description: "A brief description for SEO and previews"
tags: [python, automation, cli]
canonical_url: https://yourblog.com/your-post
published: true
---

Your content here...

docs.title: Fields
docs.text: Field Type Required Description title string Yes* Post title. Falls back to filename if not set. description string No Short description for SEO and social previews. tags list or string No Tags/hashtags. Can be YAML list or comma-separated. canonical_url string No URL of the original post (for cross-posts). published boolean No Whether to publish immediately (default: true).

docs.title: Tags Format
docs.text:
Tags can be specified in multiple formats:

# YAML list (recommended)
tags: [python, cli, automation]

# YAML list (multi-line)
tags:
  - python
  - cli
  - automation

# Comma-separated string
tags: python, cli, automation

docs.title: Blog Platforms
docs.text:
• Title: Used as article title
  • Description: Used as excerpt/subtitle
  • Tags: Applied as platform tags (may be limited, e.g., dev.to max 4)
  • Canonical URL: Set as canonical link
  • Body: Published as full article

docs.title: Social Platforms
docs.text:
• Title: Included in post text
  • Description: Included in post text (if space allows)
  • Tags: Converted to hashtags
  • Canonical URL: Appended as link
  • Body: Not used (post is a link announcement)

docs.title: Example: Blog Post
docs.text:
---
title: "Building a CLI Tool with Click"
description: "A practical guide to creating command-line interfaces in Python"
tags: [python, cli, click, tutorial]
canonical_url: https://myblog.com/click-cli-tutorial
published: true
---

# Introduction

Click is a Python package for creating beautiful command-line interfaces...

docs.title: Example: Announcement
docs.text:
For social platforms, only front matter matters:

---
title: "New Blog Post: Building a CLI Tool with Click"
description: "Learn how to create professional CLIs in Python"
tags: [python, cli]
canonical_url: https://myblog.com/click-cli-tutorial
---

This body text is ignored for social platforms.

docs.title: Draft Mode
docs.text:
Set published: false or use --draft flag:

---
title: "Work in Progress"
published: false
---

# Or via CLI
crier publish post.md --to devto --draft
